Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Broad dissatisfaction with the current tipping culture, especially the expansion of prompts to low- or no-service situations and the social pressure to tip. Many feel tipping has become coercive and “out of control.”
  • Strong support for shifting compensation responsibility from customers to employers: pay a living wage, eliminate the subminimum tipped wage, or bake compensation into menu prices. Several favor replacing tips with an automatic service charge (often cited around 10%), while others would abolish tipping entirely.
  • Clear preference for tipping to be voluntary and performance-based: reserved mainly for full-service restaurants and tied to quality of service. Many oppose tipping for pickup, drive-thru, or basic counter transactions.
  • Point-of-sale changes desired: remove default high tip prompts, present tipping as optional, provide an easy-to-find “no tip” on the first screen, and solicit tips only after service is rendered.
  • Minority views include making tipping mandatory (or standard) in some cases, setting fixed tip amounts rather than percentages, keeping tips tax-free, or encouraging universal tipping as an appreciation of skill.
  • Some suggest small gestures in return for tips (thank-you notes, coupons).
  • Common ground: workers should be fairly paid without having to rely on tips, tipping—if it remains—should reward good service rather than be expected by default, and clearer, less intrusive tipping systems would reduce pressure on consumers.

[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

answer.text_box: I deliver for Uber, Door Dash, Instacart, and Grub Hub.  I depend on tips.  I feel that in restaurants, they should pay a living wage over at least 15 an hour.  If they don't, then 18 percent at least should be added to the bills.  Some people do not tip enough or feel they should not have to.  I take issue with these people.  I personally tip 20 percent.   As a 1099 employee, it is different with the gig apps.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments:

  • General sentiment: Many express frustration with “tipping culture,” saying it has expanded beyond traditional contexts and often feels coercive, especially with point-of-sale screens that default to high tip prompts.

  • Pay and policy: The most common reform called for is shifting to livable, fair base wages so workers don’t have to rely on tips. Several suggest raising menu prices or adding a built-in service charge to replace discretionary tipping. Some propose guaranteeing at least the standard minimum wage for tipped workers, with a few advocating a specific service charge (e.g., 10%).

  • Scope and expectations: Many want tipping to be optional, tied to quality of service, and limited to situations involving meaningful service (e.g., sit-down restaurants), not for pickup, drive-thru, or minimal interaction.

  • Timing and UI: Multiple comments call for tips to be requested only after service is delivered, with clearer “no tip” options and less intrusive prompts.

  • Pro-tipping perspectives: A noticeable minority strongly support tipping as an incentive for excellent service, with some favoring mandatory tipping or higher, standardized tip amounts. A few suggest benefits for tipping (thank-you notes, coupons) and tax relief on tips.

  • Competing values: There is broad empathy for underpaid service workers alongside consumer fatigue with pressure to tip everywhere. Many say they will continue tipping under the current system while urging systemic changes that make tips a true bonus rather than a necessity.
